title: Grade 8: United States History II: Colonial America–Reconstruction
subject: Social Studies (2023-)

document.title: Connecticut Elementary and Secondary Social Studies Standards

FBF0FAAE530744C98A05CE68856D45A1.description:
Evaluate the successes and failures of the Reconstruction in fulfilling ideas and principles
contained in the founding documents (e.g., elected Black officials, Ebenezer Bassett,
Freedmen’s Bureau, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, Compromise of 1877).

C1BE36E2D915488D91280408FC7D10A2.description:
Analyze the purposes, implementation, and consequences of policies and political strategies
during the Reconstruction Era (e.g., Homestead Act, Second Treaty of Fort Laramie, women’s
suffrage, Radical Reconstruction).

C837835C7CDA4328813BFE9986F7743C.description:
Explain multiple causes and effects of racism both during and after Reconstruction (e.g., Page
Act, Ku Klux Klan, Black Codes).

C420D488158A4B07BF77C8FE0FE1C94C.description:
Analyze the causes and effects of the Reconstruction Amendments (e.g., abolition, Latino and
Black citizenship, suffrage).

0F0A3A2C722548AEA51D8CEA58FEF2A0.description:
Explain how and why individuals challenged gender roles in the Civil War Era (e.g., Loreta
Janeta Velazquez, Frances Louisa Clayton, Anna Elizabeth Dickinson, Hartford Soldiers’ Aid
Society, Rebecca Primus and Addie Brown).

75B081F93A804458B70DF9A3FA621DF9.description:
Analyze the factors that shaped perspectives in Connecticut about the Civil War (e.g., free
labor movement, role of government, abolition).

A65718F3181149FBB73D92AA212F7871.description:
Analyze factors that influenced individual and group perspectives about national identity
both during and as a result of the Civil War (e.g., Copperheads, Republicans, Wide Awakes,
Unionists, women in the industrial workforce).

E2B50CEC7DB140D89C365A1310161E20.description:
Describe how policies related to military service shaped the events and outcomes of the
Civil War (e.g., conscription, Emancipation Proclamation, draft riots, Connecticut 29th,
Massachusetts 54th).

DB09354F14AA4CA9A4EE220CA56CF47B.description:
Explain how change and continuity in technology, infrastructure, and military strategies
shaped the Civil War (e.g., rail, scorched earth, blockade, Colt Firearms, Sharps Rifles).

6FE9C268531542298B4720A0451BDAD0.description:
Compare historical means used by individuals and groups to promote, sustain, and dismantle
discrimination in the Antebellum Period (e.g., Underground Railroad, Bleeding Kansas,
American Anti-Slavery Society, American Colonization Society, Compromise of 1850).

16874A5D04414A48B1570934E8BC231C.description:
Evaluate the relative influence of political, economic, and social developments that
contributed to secession (e.g., Free Soil Movement, Nullification, Dred Scott Decision,
Harper’s Ferry, abolition).

3E89374BF99C40109A46B33C0AE228A1.description:
Using multiple historical sources, identify individuals and groups during the Antebellum
Period who sustained, promoted, or challenged the institution of slavery (e.g., Frederick
Douglass, Harriett Beecher Stowe, John C. Calhoun).

8489F5CA3F04489D9479EBE8414FBE1E.description:
Analyze how secession sought to preserve the social, economic, and racial hierarchies
throughout the United States (e.g., domestic labor, manufacturing, slavocracy, textiles).

FE7FB8373DBA4B04B3888E0B6BC3E97A.description: Civil Unrest, Civil War, and Reconstruction

1B03563A5C574538B5748214E57DAF03.description:
Analyze the role of innovation and entrepreneurship at the start of the American Industrial
Revolution (e.g., mills, patents, telegraph, interchangeable parts).

B6D10057696B47C69A2983AE113A695B.description:
Explain how the demand for finished goods influenced business specialization and the
growing need for labor during the American Industrial Revolution (e.g., textiles, firearms,
shipbuilding, manufacturing, foundries, logging).

F1F689818D0242DB859D867F8540BA85.description:
Explain how the transition from an agricultural-based economy to an industrialized economy
affected the well-being of individuals, groups, and businesses (e.g., factory workers, child
laborers, women in the industrial workforce, formerly enslaved persons, Irish, Chinese, Black,
and White laborers and tradespeople).

B0C591A2F1CB4E099935A60D784C9659.description:
Explain how Westward Expansion increased access to natural resources and the production
and distribution of goods in a global market (e.g., agriculture, mining, canals, factories, rail,
shipping).

785FAA7CC1564C108E70DB3CE4677DA0.description:
Evaluate the influence human-induced environmental change had on spatial patterns of
industrialization and Westward Expansion (e.g., Cumberland and National Roads, Erie Canal,
Farmington Canal, Pacific Railroad).

B93B04E033C54D7E81D31D45D58505AC.description:
Compare movements for social change and the strategies they employed by the United States
in the Antebellum Period (e.g., abolition, Second Great Awakening, suffrage, temperance).

3EAA6D920126424EA49F887871C792DB.description:
Analyze attempts by individuals and groups with nativist views to shape the United States in
the Antebellum Period (e.g., Philadelphia Riots of 1844, Know Nothing Party).

C64B44EDE6E346A696F003B0E1E1B953.description:
Explain the causes and effects of government policies and executive decisions related to
industrialization and expansion of the United States (e.g., Bureau of Indian Affairs, Indian
Removal Act, Louisiana Purchase, Mexican-American War).

82C74FBD7ACD4A85859F440E6AC528E4.description:
Develop questions using multiple historical sources about how individuals and groups in
northern states sustained or challenged racial inequality during the Antebellum Period (e.g.,
Connecticut’s gradual emancipation act, Amistad Trials, Sarah Harris and Prudence Crandall,
The Liberator, American Colonization Society, American Anti-Slavery Society, Underground
Railroad).

E73F21A4FF10414D8529746DCC1DE06B.description:
Analyze the perspectives of immigrant groups and their reasons for moving to and within the
United States (e.g., German, Irish, Scandinavian, Chinese, Jewish).

87066077AAF14D558F38DCFC720B6CED.description:
Develop questions to analyze the significance of the methods of resistance employed by
enslaved and free Black people in the United States (e.g., work resistance, violence, sabotage,
petition, forming maroon communities, independent churches, and educational associations).

DBC08724926941888481D013A2DC076F.description:
Analyze the events and developments related to the institution of slavery in the early republic
(e.g., Haitian Revolution, Act Prohibiting the Importation of Slaves, cotton gin, textile industry).

E96999C587714A8EB56D947818E2A584.description:
Analyze the impact of United States’ treaties on the sovereignty of Native nations (e.g.,
Ordinance of 1787, Treaty of the Creeks, Treaty of Greenville, Louisiana Purchase, Treaty of
Fort Wayne).

9A9DE35D9FCF401BAE14A4FD9FACD4F7.description:
Evaluate the US Constitution and Bill of Rights to determine if the goals of the American
Revolution, as stated in the Declaration of Independence, were realized.

40D89B2A623944569ECA0CCB678EC6BE.description:
Explain the relevance of democratic principles in shaping acts of dissent and resistance in
early United States history (e.g., Whiskey Rebellion, Shay’s Rebellion, Nat Turner’s Rebellion).

5D5C43134F864884BB2764AE48B7EA91.description:
Analyze how ideas and principles about citizenship and access to political power expressed
in founding documents influenced social and political systems in the early republic (e.g., Bill
of Rights, Declaration of Independence, Three-Fifths Clause, Electoral College).

70B63A90B06A48BF9523221DA5818A69.description:
Analyze how the ideas and principles within the Bill of Rights influence the social and political
system in the United States.

789A5C0BE6B64EFBAAE74D1B4B5E4196.description:
Explain the perspectives, civic virtues, and democratic principles debated during the
Constitutional Convention (e.g., Connecticut Compromise, federalism, Three-Fifths
Compromise).

8B7AEE52B0CC42198E2ED4B66F64F58B.description:
Explain the evolving powers and limits of the three branches of government as defined in the
United States Constitution and subsequent federal court rulings, legislation, and executive
action (e.g., Alien and Sedition Acts, Marbury v. Madison, Treaty of San Lorenzo).

5C1CD38AA88A4859A18902AA530CF9F2.description:
Examine the origin, purpose, and impact of the founding documents (e.g., popular
sovereignty, republicanism, separation of powers, enfranchisement, liberty).

F5842CC07D8B44EDB2B7BDEC04829EF3.description:
Explain laws that institutionalized slavery in the Colonial Era and in the Constitution (e.g.,
Black Laws of Virginia, Fugitive Slave Act, Three-Fifths Clause).

14913B00CAB84E03B3E8037631883433.description:
Describe how individual and group perspectives of the American Revolution are documented
in historical records while identifying representation of marginalized voices (e.g., journals,
letters, pamphlets, newspaper articles from sources such as the Hartford Daily Courant).

7F4AD188C865497384E5033F296B16A3.description:
Analyze factors that influenced perspectives about national identity both during and as a
result of the American Revolution (e.g., social contract, individual liberties, tyranny, economic
and political sovereignty, citizenship).

BFB690A1A1CF477DBBDADE82E6F3343E.description:
Analyze the perspectives of both enslaved and free Black people through the historical
sources they created (e.g., Venture Smith, Phyllis Wheatley, Olaudah Equiano).

EE21F928B81A4872B7A52238E4CE1A4E.description:
Explain the events and developments that led to the establishment of colonies in the Atlantic
and Pacific Worlds (e.g., desire for religious liberty, natural resources, economic opportunities,
technological advancements).

3EEACEECC09D44A3B64640484275FBED.description: Origins of United States Democracy and National Identity

6516BA7303B042E18956DABD81400724.description:
Apply a range of deliberative and democratic procedures to make decisions and take
action in classrooms, schools, and out-of-school civic contexts.

D4E7E8AAA9D847EEB77789B366E342CB.description:
Analyze how a specific problem can manifest itself at local, regional, and global levels over
time, identifying its characteristics and causes, and the challenges and opportunities faced
by those trying to address the problem.

F7A9711879F14985B80DC6009E2EA347.description:
Present arguments and explanations that feature multiple perspectives about local, state,
or national history to reach a target audience using print, oral, and digital technologies.

FE415B4B46294ADFB50C748B740F78A0.description:
Critique the credibility of arguments and structure of explanations related to a historical
account of an event or issue in United States history.

D24777DA97424C2891CCA9FC7B91E72B.description:
Construct explanations using reasoning, summary, sequence, examples, and data while
pointing out the strengths and weaknesses of the explanations.

CB10724E7E244A5FA2925AD75E6DFAAE.description:
Construct arguments using evidence from multiple sources, while acknowledging the
strengths and limitations of the arguments.

190E4DD5A24543939F7DDCFB640A50EF.description: Communicate Conclusions and Take Informed Action

11ECE993BBB4415D9A518DC4965069F0.description:
Develop claims and counterclaims while pointing out the strengths and limitations of
different sources.

95D4E7EF651C4EF8B3446B611E37894B.description: Organize and prioritize relevant evidence from and among multiple sources to support claims.

C7A3E8BDCE02432FBA742D630BC751A5.description:
Gather information from multiple sources and evaluate their relevance and intended use
(e.g., origin, authority, structure, context, corroborative value, credibility).

6515949F056A4CB78616752D079F88B9.description:
Apply disciplinary knowledge and practices to demonstrate an understanding of United
States history content.

08F25763290240AC91FA8DFB1E9C8907.description:
Determine the kinds of sources that will be helpful in answering compelling and supporting
questions, taking into consideration multiple points of views represented in the sources.

CB3966E6394F4C40AD831881BCCF871E.description: Develop compelling and supporting questions that are mutually reinforcing.

EF2E8439EADB4B05A87A965C4DB423D6.description:
Explain how compelling and supporting questions represent key ideas in the study of
United States history.
